name: NewYorker
text:
If Congress and the Trump Administration fail to step in, the human and economic toll of the pandemic will likely get even larger than the one outlined in the jobs report.
https://t.co/mzc0cJu83B

name: NewYorker
text: The 1999 movie “Drop Dead Gorgeous” is offensive, for sure—but it is also hilarious, surprisingly tender, and lavishly, magnificently absurd, @jiatolentino writes. https://t.co/olyzhpl7tn

name: NewYorker
text: Right now, Joe Biden’s strategy of keeping the focus on President Trump and pitching a broad tent is working well, @JohnCassidy writes. https://t.co/OEFlECtnjJ

name: NewYorker
text: America's system of government, its stated values, and its claims to greatness are all under siege by a President who lacks the moral compass, self-doubt, and respect for historical norms that would restrain another leader, @JohnCassidy writes. https://t.co/PiW6mC1GNn

name: NewYorker
text:
"She Dies Tomorrow" is a metaphysical science-fiction film about a strange and extreme new form of mortal contagion—and a woman who is seized with the idea that she will die the next day.
https://t.co/hqely64LuM

name: NewYorker
text:
Jamaica, a nation whose economy is dependent on international movement and tourism, had no choice but to reopen. But opening its borders to Americans puts the country’s population at risk.
https://t.co/IbdNDUzxkU

name: NewYorker
text: A series of tender, exacting black-and-white photographs captures the daily walks Julia and Paul Child took almost every day during their years in France. https://t.co/WjlLA58CWF

name: NewYorker
text:
The new documentary "Boys State" focusses on a group of politically inclined teens who, should their dreams come true, will be running the country someday.
https://t.co/Vp2Gdaz4oL

name: NewYorker
text:
Shakespeare lived his entire life in the shadow of bubonic plague—epidemic disease is ever-present in his work as a steady, low-level undertone.
https://t.co/cqVeRi00Rz

name: NewYorker
text: “Jayhawkers” is a first-person movie about the historical record as inextricably linked to the inner life, and about how to get both onto the screen together. https://t.co/3Tz5mZxYnM

name: NewYorker
text: Any study of the codpiece begins with two simple questions: Why did it exist at all, and why did men elect to wear it?https://t.co/z8QWwJTUPr

name: NewYorker
text:
In the early 1980s, “The Far Side” became one of the smartest and most inventive daily comics of the late 20th century. Now its creator has returned after 25 years in retirement.
https://t.co/tYApDY2wna

name: NewYorker
text:
"For those who can take a stolen moment of repose, the Nap Dress has a tranquillizing allure," @rachsyme writes. "It is a clean slate, white noise, a gauzy, brief escape for those who can afford it."
https://t.co/FNWKYUkLs1

name: NewYorker
text: As tuberculosis shaped modernism, so COVID-19 and our collective experience of staying inside for months on end will influence architecture’s near future, @chaykak writes. https://t.co/QaSrhXL1w1
